author: By Sam Roberts
title: Gene Norman, Who Helped Landmark Broadway Theaters, Dies at 85
description: As chairman of New York’s preservation commission, he also oversaw the preservation of St. Bartholomew’s Church, the Coney Island Cyclone and Ladies’ Mile.
content: Gene Norman, who as New York City’s unflappable official preservationist was instrumental in sparing Broadway theaters, St. Bartholomew’s Church and the Coney Island Cyclone from destruction or defacement by developers, died on Aug. 30 at his home in the Bronx. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Congress Should Pass a Navalny Act
description: The latest poisoning of a Russian critic requires expanded sanctions and accountability for Kremlin leadership.
content: In 2012, in the face of quiet resistance from the Obama administration, Congress passed the Magnitsky Act, named for a Russian lawyer, Sergei Magnitsky, who was left to die in a Moscow prison in 2009 for blowing the whistle on a $230 million scam perpetrated by government officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: The Trump Docket: A Look at the Fights Fueling Trump’s Big Legal Bills
description: Donor money is helping pay for a dizzying array of litigation filed by the president or against him.
content: WASHINGTON — Long before he moved into the White House, Donald J. Trump had cemented his reputation as a lover of lawsuits, turning to federal and state courts for battles big and small. Mr. Trump once even boasted, “I like beating my enemies to the ground.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: With Bucks Facing Elimination, Uncertainty Grows Around Giannis Antetokounmpo
description: For the second consecutive year, the Bucks entered the playoffs with the league’s best regular-season record. Down 3-0 against the Miami Heat, questions are swirling around the future of the team and its superstar.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Before the Milwaukee Bucks labored through a stretch of basketball that could wind up altering their future, Giannis Antetokounmpo did something that he tends to do well: He elevated for a dunk, a brief burst of explosiveness that gave the Bucks a fourth-quarter lead against the Miami Heat in Game 3 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron and Michelle V. Agins
title: How the Circle Drive-In ‘Found Its Niche’ in the Pandemic
description: With a flea market, graduations and even a livestreamed country music concert, a Pennsylvania Drive-in became a safe gathering place.
content: In the coronavirus pandemic, it became 15 acres of safety, 15 acres where people could lose themselves in a crowd but remain alone as they watched a movie. Or graduated from high school. Or played bingo. Or watched fireworks. Or hummed along at a concert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thessaly La Force
title: 7 Sculpture Gardens that Merge Art With the Landscape
description: This fall, getting culture outdoors is even more restorative than usual. Here are some options across the country.
content: Many museums and galleries across the country have cautiously begun to reopen in recent weeks, offering a chance for the culture-starved to enjoy a moment of reprieve with their favorite works of art. Still, the lines can be long, and timed ticketing limits a more impulsive visit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Could You Repeat That Number?
description: David Kwong doubles down on the fun and takes us out to the old ballgame, too.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Beware the sleight of word running through this brilliantly tortuous puzzle. David Kwong, magician, TED Talk whisperer and puzzle conjurer is back, and I couldn’t be happier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: How Trump Draws on Campaign Funds to Pay Legal Bills
description: As he has done with other aspects of the presidency, Donald J. Trump has redefined the practice in ways that have unsettled even some Republicans.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump was proudly litigious before his victory in 2016 and has remained so in the White House. But one big factor has changed: He has drawn on campaign donations as a piggy bank for his legal expenses to a degree far greater than any of his predecessors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serena Solomon
title: ‘Dwarf Pride’ Was Hard Won. Will a Growth Drug Undermine It?
description: An experimental medication that increases height in children with the most common form of dwarfism has raised hope that it can help them lead easier lives. But some say the condition is not a problem in need of a cure.
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — It’s a question many parents of children with dwarfism have contemplated: If a medication could make them taller, would they give it to them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Benefit From a Fall Routine
description: Your days don’t need to look the same every single day, but recognizing and honoring a schedule brings plenty of mental and physical benefits.
content: As the pandemic continues and the school year starts up, some people might be craving some regularity and structure. Having a routine not only guides you through your days, but it also brings mental and physical benefits, too, whether by adding exercise to your day, aiding in getting better sleep, helping children feel more secure or providing a sense of control during such an uncertain time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Ben Rothenberg
title: The U.S. Open Descends Into Pandemic Precaution Chaos
description: Yet another change in rules for players who were exposed to a player who tested positive for coronavirus caused the top women’s doubles team to be defaulted.
content: For two weeks, all seemed well with the plan to hold the United States Open in New York just a few months after the city had become the epicenter for the coronavirus in the Western world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 5, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 5, 2020
content: An article on Friday about spit hoods, a device used by to prevent people from biting or spitting, misspelled the surname of a professor of police science at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. She is Maria Haberfeld, not Haberfield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: First Famines of Coronavirus Era Are at World’s Doorstep, U.N. Warns
description: The top U.N. relief official said parts of Yemen, South Sudan, northeast Nigeria and the Democratic Republic of Congo are at risk, “endangering the lives of millions of women, men and children.”
content: The first famines of the coronavirus era could soon hit four chronically food-deprived conflict areas — Yemen, South Sudan, northeast Nigeria and the Democratic Republic of Congo — the top humanitarian official of the United Nations has warned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Land in Russia’s Arctic Blows ‘Like a Bottle of Champagne’
description: Since finding the first crater in 2014, Russian scientists have documented 16 more explosions in the Arctic caused by gas trapped in thawing permafrost.
content: MOSCOW — A natural phenomenon first observed by scientists just six years ago and now recurring with alarming frequency in Siberia is causing the ground to explode spontaneously and with tremendous force, leaving craters up to 100 feet deep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Moves to Cancel Contracts for Government Sensitivity Training
description: A memo sent to agency heads on Friday called efforts that often focus on promoting awareness of racism “divisive” and “un-American propaganda.”
content: President Trump has directed administration officials to make significant changes to sensitivity training sessions across the government, calling such efforts that often focus on promoting awareness of racism “divisive” and “un-American propaganda.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How Many of These 68,000 Deaths Could Have Been Avoided?
description: Nursing home residents and staff members account for around 40 percent of coronavirus-related deaths in the U.S. There’s no justifiable reason for that.
content: Jose Velasquez, a 79-year-old father from Bexar County, Texas, tested positive for the coronavirus on March 26 and died on April 17. During those weeks, the staff at the nursing home where he lived assured his family that he showed no symptoms of Covid-19 and, according to a lawsuit filed by his children, failed to ensure that he received proper medical care. The staff did not transfer him to a hospital as he deteriorated or even warn his family that he was sick, according to the suit. Mr. Velasquez’s family says that just hours before he died, the staff at the home reported he was “doing fine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christy Harmon
title: Remember Your Summer With Sun Prints
description: Use those shells, dried flower and other keepsakes to create beautiful white-and-blue prints.
content: Whether you went to the seaside or the mountains or stayed local this summer, chances are you have a pile of natural keepsakes, picked up while wandering, which now sit in a bowl or on a table in your home. Not sure what to do with them? You can use those shells, dried flowers or other mementos to make a unique and everlasting sun print.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: After Cancer Treatment, Oskar Lindblom Is Back in the Fray
description: Lindblom, 24, suited up for the Philadelphia Flyers for the first time since December on Thursday in a postseason elimination game and could play in Game 7 on Saturday.
content: Oskar Lindblom had described his surgery and extensive chemotherapy treatment as “hell” earlier in the season. He had said he felt like a potential return to the ice was eons away after his first treatment for bone cancer and the ensuing push-and-pull of recovering from treatments that for months alternated between moderate and severe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Serena Williams Beats Sloane Stephens at U.S. Open
description: Williams, the No. 3 seed, won after dropping the first set to Stephens.
content: Another comeback victory in the books, Serena Williams waved to two of the very rare spectators at this twilight zone of a United States Open: her husband Alexis Ohanian and their daughter, Olympia, who turned 3 this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: ‘A Glorious Thing to Be’
description: John Guzzetta mines the alphabet for hardworking words at just the right time of year.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I thought I was detecting a theme where there should be none. It is Saturday, isn’t it? These days it’s hard to tell sometimes. But there is a repeated combo, “ER,” that keeps popping up at the ends of the answers here. It brings to mind those workhorses, the makers and doers: the BUTCHER, BAKER, TINKER (TINKERER?). The answers ending in “ER,” even though they don’t necessarily relate to jobs, are certainly weight-bearing words, and what better time for them than Labor Day weekend?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Authentic Wins the Kentucky Derby, Run Without Fans
description: The race in Louisville ran with a smaller field than usual, no spectators and in spite of nearby protests over the police killing of Breonna Taylor in the city earlier this year.
content: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — No one really expected a horse race.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Northeastern University Dismisses 11 Students for Breaking Virus Rules but Keeps Their Tuition
description: The U.N. warns of looming famines connected to the pandemic. Melbourne, Australia’s second-biggest city, has extended its lockdown by two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Risks and Tradeoffs in the Covid Era
description: Readers discuss human nature and decisions about acceptable risks and sacrifices in response to the coronavirus.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin and The New York Times
title: 11 Students on a First Day of School Like No Other
description: Students across the country discussed math, masks and managing anxiety as the year begins.
content: Lucas Fonte’s first day of virtual third grade was a virtual flop. There was no exciting wait for the school bus or morning greeting from the bus driver, Mrs. Rodriguez. Instead, the talkative eight-year-old put on his school uniform shirt, sat down next to his mother and brother at the dining room table and tried to log on to the Miami-Dade Public School district’s new online learning platform.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Last Year, Dance Class. This Year, Lessons About Justice.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 5, 2020.
content: “For me, being a young Black woman, I’m just focused on my life. That’s really why I’m out here. I am just a Black girl trying to live.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: If Summer Were a Meatball
description: Make Melissa Clark’s recipe, or any of the most popular recipes of the week.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Melissa Clark’s skillet meatballs with peaches, basil and lime (above), Jerrelle Guy’s cherry-almond granola crisp and Hetty McKinnon’s herby tomato salad with tamarind-maple dressing. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: How to Both Work and School From Home
description: The hours blur together, sure, but creating distinct spaces, keeping a schedule and sharing resources can help.
content: In March, several days before the coronavirus pandemic brought New York to a halt, Mary Ausman, a parent and church educational coordinator, moved with her husband, their two sons and two dogs from a house in the Riverdale neighborhood of the Bronx to a 600-square-foot apartment in Hell’s Kitchen. The family wanted their younger son, Alex, 10, a student at the School of American Ballet in Midtown, to be able to walk to dance rehearsals and acting auditions, and looked forward to living in a more central location.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Trussoni
title: Grisly Slabs of Gothic Horror
description: These books — both fiction and nonfiction — celebrate the dark corners of our world.
content: In the introduction to WEIRD WOMEN: Classic Supernatural Fiction by Groundbreaking Female Writers 1852-1923 (Pegasus, 384 pp., $25.95), the editors Lisa Morton and Leslie S. Klinger write that horror often seems to be a “genre bereft of female writers.” Here they set out to correct that misperception, highlighting stories by women writers whose work has fallen into obscurity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: What to Watch at the 146th Kentucky Derby
description: The race in Louisville will have a smaller field than usual, no spectators and run as protests continue nearby after the police killing of Breonna Taylor in the city earlier this year.
content: LOUISVILLE — The 146th running of the Kentucky Derby is going to be one of the strangest editions of America’s most famous race, beginning with the date of the race: The first Saturday in September rather than its traditional place on the calendar in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: 4 Dead in Philadelphia House Fire
description: The victims were 9, 11, 17 and 35 years old, officials said.
content: A woman, a teenager and two children were found dead in a fire at a Philadelphia rowhouse on Saturday morning, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: John Kelly, at Center of Report on Trump Disparaging U.S. Soldiers, Keeps Silent
description: The former chief of staff’s public reticence has frustrated groups that are hoping that he will publicly endorse Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee.
content: WASHINGTON — John F. Kelly left the White House barely on speaking terms with President Trump. In the months since, Mr. Kelly, a retired four-star general and former White House chief of staff, has stayed mostly silent as other senior military figures have publicly and harshly criticized the president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randal C. Archibold
title: A Son’s Future, a Father’s Final Down
description: In Jacqueline Woodson’s “Before the Ever After,” a boy struggles to move forward as his pro football star father’s memory fades.
content: BEFORE THE EVER AFTERBy Jacqueline Woodson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: International Crime Ring That Trafficked in Shark Fins Is Dismantled, U.S. Says
description: Law enforcement agents documented the harvest of more than six tons of shark fins, officials said.
content: Shark fin soup, considered a delicacy in some countries, has long fueled demand for illegally harvested fins. But federal authorities in Georgia announced this week that they had dismantled at least one source for the ingredient: a multimillion-dollar organization they described as an international money laundering, drug trafficking and illegal wildlife trade ring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Between the Pandemic and the President: Mexico City Mayor’s Balancing Act
description: As the first woman and Jewish person elected to lead the capital, Claudia Sheinbaum needs the president’s support. But how close can she remain to a man who has downplayed the pandemic?
content: MEXICO CITY — It was a perfect portrait of the delicate relationship between the Mexican president and his protégée.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: ‘Agricultural Jihad’: A Hungry Lebanon Returns to Family Farms to Feed Itself
description: With a tanking economy, and imported food costs soaring, leaders are urging the Lebanese to wage a campaign of self-sufficiency. “I never thought I’d do this in my life, but I have to survive.”
content: ANTELIAS, Lebanon — The falafel shop owner leaned back and listed the keys to the Lebanese kitchen — the staples that help lend this country its culinary halo:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Sheera Frenkel
title: Parents Got More Time Off. Then the Backlash Started.
description: Pandemic policies at tech companies have created a rift between parents offered more benefits and resentful workers who don’t have children.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — When the coronavirus closed schools and child care centers and turned American parenthood into a multitasking nightmare, many tech companies rushed to help their employees. They used their comfortable profit margins to extend workers new benefits, including extra time off for parents to help them care for their children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2020 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Saturday
description: The defending doubles champions play their second-round matches, and the 2019 singles runners-up, Daniil Medvedev and Serena Williams, start off Saturday’s slate with third-round matches at Arthur Ashe Stadium.
content: How to watch: From 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN2; streaming on the ESPN app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas, Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Pharma Companies Plan Joint Pledge on Vaccine Safety
description: The statement is meant to reassure the public that the companies will not seek a premature approval of vaccines under pressure from the Trump administration.
content: A group of drug companies competing with one another to be among the first to develop coronavirus vaccines are planning to pledge early next week that they will not release any vaccines that do not follow rigorous efficacy and safety standards, according to representatives of three of the companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mohammed Hanif
title: What I’ve Learned From Teaching Online
description: Roll call becomes a roster of absences. Some students write fantasies of escape. Can a new life begin when you are confined with siblings and parents?
content: “Let’s read,” I told the students in my writing class, trying to invoke the authority of my own high-school literature teacher. I was hoping they would unzip their backpacks, pull out the books and start reading. I had become a visiting teacher at a university in Karachi, Pakistan, a couple of years before the pandemic, and I was struggling. It felt nice to be called a professor, but I was reluctant to call my students, “my students.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Charges 2 With Trying to Support Hamas
description: The men, both American citizens, were taken into custody on Thursday evening in Minneapolis. They say they are members of a far-right group called the Boogaloo Bois.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Friday charged two American citizens with ties to a far-right extremist group with trying to support the Palestinian terrorist group Hamas — a case that shows that extremists have sought to turn protests against racism into opportunities to commit violence, but that also runs counter to President Trump’s assertions that those extremists are predominantly on the far left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: U.S. Open Match Delayed as Health Officials Debate Virus Rules
description: Alexander Zverev and Adrian Mannarino waited more than two hours to play their match as officials debated whether Mannarino should play given his contact with another player who tested positive for coronavirus.
content: A third-round United States Open men’s singles match between Alexander Zverev and Adrian Mannarino was delayed for more than two hours on Friday as government health officials and tournament officials debated whether Mannarino should be allowed to play because of his contact with another player who tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: A Big 2020 Campaign Question: Wait, What Day Is It?
description: Time is marching on, toward Election Day. Somehow.
content: What day is it today? Is it:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock, Dera Menra Sijabat and Ulet Ifansasti
title: When Learning Is Really Remote: Students Climb Trees and Travel Miles for a Cell Signal
description: Schools are closed in Indonesia because of the pandemic, but for the rural poor who lack internet access and smartphones, online education is particularly difficult.
content: On school days, the three teenage students hop on a motorbike and ride to their personal study hall: a spot along a narrow road outside the Indonesian village of Kenalan where they can get a stable cellphone signal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: After Accusations of Police Cover-Up, Prude Case Goes to Grand Jury
description: The decision by New York’s attorney general comes more than five months after Daniel Prude died of suffocation after officers in Rochester, N.Y., placed a hood over his head.
content: New York’s attorney general announced on Saturday that she would set up a grand jury to consider evidence in the death of a Black man in Rochester, N.Y., who suffocated after he had been placed in a hood by police officers and pinned to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: The Battle Over Biscuits and Gravy at the 11-Worth Cafe
description: In “levelheaded” Omaha, a protester was killed and, in the aftermath, people demanding an end to racial injustice set their sights on police budgets — and a diner with Robert E. Lee on the menu.
content: Omaha’s 11-Worth Cafe served standard American breakfast fare of omelets, hash browns, bacon and eggs and, without much notice until June, a dish called the Robert E. Lee: two sausage patties smooshed between biscuits and smothered in gravy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julfikar Ali Manik and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Explosion at Mosque, Likely Caused by Gas Leak, Kills 16 in Bangladesh
description: Dozens of worshipers were severely burned in the blast on Friday night just outside Dhaka.
content: An explosion on Friday night at a mosque near Bangladesh’s capital, believed to have been caused by a gas leak, killed at least 16 worshipers and left 21 with burns so severe that the death toll could rise further, according to a police officer and a doctor treating some of the victims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: When These Sea Anemones Eat, It Goes Straight to Their Arms
description: They’re the first animals known to turn food into extra limbs.
content: People have a lot of strategies for dealing with the effects of large meals — constitutionals, antacids, workouts, naps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Von Ehren and Andrew Dore
title: Follow a Pandemic-Themed Path
description: This year a whole new vocabulary has sprung up. Find the words that have been central to reveal something essential.
content: For Labor Day weekend, here’s a word maze. It’s like an old-fashioned word search with a twist. The rules are fairly simple: You are looking for quarantine-related words and phrases secreted among the jumble of letters. Start at the dog-eared “C” and follow a path ending at the similarly marked “E.” You may move only horizontally or vertically, not diagonally. Letters may be visited only once, and the end of one word is always adjacent to the start of the next. If you color each square along your route with a colored pen or pencil, it will reveal a hidden image. Oh, and, as in life, avoid COVID. Download the game here and print to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Druckerman
title: Lockdown Left My Mind and Body Flabby. Then Came Tennis Camp.
description: What playing doubles with a Parisian urologist taught me about how to get my life in order.
content: PARIS — While many Americans were cooped up at home or learning to love camping, in France (and many other places in Europe) we had an almost normal summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Dorothy Parker’s Ashes Are Returned to New York
description: Completing a decades-long journey, the writer’s ashes were disinterred in Baltimore and taken by train to their (latest) final resting place: Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx.
content: The ashes of Dorothy Parker, the beloved writer and humorist, have been moved yet again, this time to a final resting spot in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Top Biden Advisers Preview Fall Election Strategy
description: In a wide-ranging briefing less than two months before Election Day, Joe Biden’s team said that he and Kamala Harris would be ramping up in-person activities and travel.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee, and his running mate, Senator Kamala Harris, are planning an accelerated in-person travel schedule and the campaign is ramping up its on-the-ground activities as the 2020 race hurtles into its homestretch. Top Biden advisers detailed the new strategy in a conference call on Friday and described the contest as fundamentally steady despite the volatility of the news environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Allentuck
title: The Best Part of Layshia Clarendon’s Game? ‘Fearlessness’
description: “It doesn’t matter if I get blocked — I’m going to go right back in the paint again,” the Liberty guard said. They bring that same tenacity to their role on the W.N.B.A. union’s executive committee.
content: On the court, Layshia Clarendon has become the leader of a young Liberty team coursing through a season with many unexpected challenges. As an executive committee member of the W.N.B.A.’s players’ union, Clarendon has also become a voice for social justice for the league this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Eleanor Jacobs, 91, Dies; a Force Behind the Earth Shoe Phenomenon
description: After discovering a pair in Copenhagen that eased her back pain, she and her husband rebranded the funny-looking shoe and sold millions in the U.S.
content: Eleanor Jacobs, who stumbled upon a pair of odd-looking shoes in Denmark and, with her husband, Raymond, created a short-lived phenomenon by selling them in the United States as Earth Shoes, died on Aug. 25 at her home in Litchfield, Conn. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: McGuire or Maguire? A Tussle Over Who Founded Labor Day
description: Descendants of two men with similar last names claim their great-grandfather was the true father of the holiday.
content: TOTOWA, N.J. — For nearly 50 years, Bill Collins, a retired history teacher, spent Labor Day not at a beach or a barbecue, but at a cemetery. He and a dozen or more relatives would gather around the tombstone of his great-grandfather to celebrate his founding of the national workers’ holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: Color of Change: Tackling Systemic Racism One Strategy at a Time
description: Rashad Robinson, president of Color of Change, talks about the online racial justice organization’s 15 years of work — and its strategies during a summer of unrest.
content: [Race/Related is available as a newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Variety: Split Decisions
description: Fred Piscop presents us with many forks in the road.
content: VARIETY PUZZLE — It has been a long time since I’ve done one of Fred Piscop’s “Split Decisions” puzzles, and it shows. When I was “in practice,” the word pairs fell easily for me, but not this time. If that is not a good testimonial for solving regularly, I don’t know what is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Readers Share Their Best Unexpected Wedding Photos
description: A selection of cherished, unplanned and unscripted, wedding moments submitted by our readers.
content: Inspired by Alix Strauss’s article where wedding photographers shared their favorite wedding photos, we asked readers to submit their own candid, unscripted photos from their special day. Here is a selection of their cherished moments (all from weddings long before social distancing was upon us). From an explosion of laughter at the altar, to an unexpected trash the dress (and tux) session, these photos prove that the best moments are sometimes unplanned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Court Approves Warrantless Surveillance Rules While Scolding F.B.I.
description: The release of a newly declassified ruling follows a separate decision by an appeals court that a defunct National Security Agency program was illegal.
content: WASHINGTON — The nation’s surveillance court found that the F.B.I. had committed “widespread violations” of rules intended to protect Americans’ privacy when analysts search through a repository of emails gathered without a warrant, but it nevertheless signed off on another year of the program, according to a newly declassified ruling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Joseph Bartscherer, Rigorously Conceptual Photographer, Dies at 65
description: His work — including a project for which he collected three decades of front-page obituaries from The New York Times — often took years to complete.
content: Joseph Bartscherer, a fine-art photographer who created rigorously conceptual work about the constructed world, the natural world and the intersection of the two, was found dead on Aug. 13 at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent in Russia Inquiry Says Trump Is a National Security Threat
description: Peter Strzok, who was fired for sending anti-Trump texts, played a central role in both the Hillary Clinton email and Trump-Russia investigations.
content: WASHINGTON — A former senior F.B.I. agent at the center of the investigations into Hillary Clinton’s email server and the Trump campaign’s ties to Russia defends the handling of the inquiries and declares President Trump a national security threat in a new memoir, while admitting that the bureau made mistakes that upended the 2016 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katy Hershberger
title: Two Suicidal Teens, Four Possible Paths
description: Aaron and Tillie are strangers, until they meet on a bridge. Bill Konigsberg’s new novel explores where four different plotlines could take them.
content: THE BRIDGEBy Bill Konigsberg
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: ‘I Keep My Promises,’ Trump Said. Let’s Check.
description: Here’s a report card on whether the president met his 2016 campaign pledges.
content: Four years ago as a candidate, President Trump made more than 280 campaign promises. Let’s see how he did:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: How to Pass the Time This Weekend
description: Things to watch, eat, read and do as summer comes to a close.
content: Welcome. It’s Labor Day weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Coronavirus May Change College Admissions Forever
description: A pandemic returns the focus to what matters: education.
content: In the context of a pandemic that has killed about 190,000 Americans and economically devastated many millions more, getting into the college of your dreams is a boutique concern. But for many teenagers who have organized their school years around that goal, it’s everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Annie Karni
title: The Latest Polls, the Great Non-Tightening: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: A wave of data this week suggested that the race was largely holding steady after the parties’ conventions. Will the uproar over President Trump’s reported remarks on the military shake things up?
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch and Aimee Ortiz
title: At Least 4 Boats Sink During ‘Trump Boat Parade’ in Texas, Officials Say
description: No injuries were immediately reported at the event, which was taking place on Lake Travis.
content: The authorities rescued numerous people from the waters of Lake Travis in Texas on Saturday after at least four boats sank at an event promoted as a Trump Boat Parade, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Momigliano
title: Famous in Italy, Rodari Reaches U.S. Shores With ‘Telephone Tales’
description: The children’s book writer never caught on in America, partly because of his Communist Party ties, but the English-language release of his masterpiece could change that.
content: EUPILIO, Italy — One of Gianni Rodari’s short stories is set in a faraway land where the authorities are so meek that, when a visitor picks a forbidden flower, a police officer demands to be slapped across the face. The visitor refuses to comply with such a strange order — if anything, he says, it’s the police who should slap him — but the reader is left wondering if reality is any less absurd.
source.name: The New York Times

title: College Football During a Pandemic? (or Ever?)
description: Readers expand on an argument made in an editorial.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: When Did the Suburbs Get so LOUD?
description: Several municipalities around New York have urged homeowners to limit the use of noisy landscaping equipment because their neighbors are home during the pandemic.
content: Q: I just moved from New York City to the suburbs and assumed I’d need time to adjust to the quiet. I was wrong. The noise from the leaf blowers and lawn mowers is constant and so loud. No sooner has a landscaping crew finished eviscerating the grass at one house, than another arrives to mow the next. Does this go on all the time? How do people tolerate it? Are there no regulations about this kind of noise?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: 100 Days of Protest: A Chasm Grows Between Portland and the Rest of Oregon
description: The proximity of the left and the right in Oregon has created a dynamic of fear, mistrust and anger.
content: SANDY, Ore. — Trucks carrying bales of hay, horse paddocks and Christmas tree farms — drive a few miles out of Portland and the suburbs quickly give way to rural Oregon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: A Growing Number of Catholic Schools Are Shutting Down Forever
description: About 150 Catholic schools have closed nationwide citing insurmountable financial pressures from the coronavirus pandemic.
content: In more than four decades of coaching girls’ basketball at Lebanon Catholic High School in southeastern Pennsylvania, Patti Hower had led the team to three state championships and 20 district titles. This year, with four starting players returning, there were high hopes again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Many Lives Would a More Normal President Have Saved?
description: Trump failed to meet the Covid-19 challenge. But it’s harder to judge whether the overall response was catastrophic or merely mediocre.
content: All of the fears I nurtured in 2016 about Donald Trump’s unfitness for the presidency, and the dangers of putting him in the White House for the sake of judicial appointments or tax cuts or any other policy goal, have seemingly been vindicated so far in 2020. Combine Trump’s conduct throughout the Covid-19 pandemic — the month of denial, the veering messaging and policy, the rage-tweeting, the shrugging surrender to a summer spike — with the growing toll of American dead, and you have the strongest case for NeverTrumpism, distilled: Never mind his policy positions, never mind the perils of liberalism; the risk of a once-in-a-century catastrophe with this guy in charge is just too high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Michael Venutolo-Mantovani
title: Race for Coronavirus Vaccine Pits Spy Against Spy
description: The intelligence wars over vaccine research have intensified as China and Russia expand their efforts to steal American work at both research institutes and companies.
content: WASHINGTON — Chinese intelligence hackers were intent on stealing coronavirus vaccine data, so they looked for what they believed would be an easy target. Instead of simply going after pharmaceutical companies, they conducted digital reconnaissance on the University of North Carolina and other schools doing cutting-edge research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Searchers Find No Sign of Survivor in Beirut Rubble
description: The searchers said there were no new indications that anyone was alive in the rubble of a historic house that was destroyed by the blast, despite possible signs of life reported earlier.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rescue workers who had spent days searching for a possible survivor in a building destroyed by a huge explosion last month all but gave up hope on Saturday, saying they had no new indications that anyone was alive under the rubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Coronavirus Crisis Shatters India’s Big Dreams
description: The country’s ambitions to become a global power, lift its poor and update its military have been set back by a sharp economic plunge, soaring infections and a widening sense of malaise.
content: SURAT, India — The hit that India’s dreams have taken from the coronavirus pandemic can be found in the hushed streets of Surat’s industrial zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: With More Black Women, U.S. Open Shows Serena and Venus Legacy
description: “It’s amazing to see so many girls that look like me playing in the tournament and the main draw,” said Hailey Baptiste, 18, who received a U.S. Open wild card.
content: The main event of the United States Open on Saturday will be Serena Williams playing Sloane Stephens: a third-round duel between Williams, the greatest women’s tennis player of her era, and Stephens, the last American to win a U.S. Open singles title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Recreational Adrenaline: Three Sizzling New Thrillers
description: Late summer is supposed to be a slow time for publishers, but this year there’s plenty to get your heart racing.
content: Late summer is supposed to be a doldrum-y time in publishing, but this year brings an enticing crop of thrillers of all kinds. Along comes Alex Pavesi’s THE EIGHTH DETECTIVE (Holt, 289 pp., $26.99), for instance, which had me at its author bio: “He enjoys puzzles, long walks and recreational lock picking.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Professor Investigated for Posing as Black Won’t Teach This Term, Officials Say
description: George Washington University said the professor, Jessica A. Krug, will not have classes this semester after a blog post published under her name described her use of Black identities even though she is white.
content: A George Washington University professor who is being investigated after a blog post published under her name said that she had posed as a Black woman will not teach classes this semester, the university said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Flat Polls. Weak Ratings. Do Political Conventions Have a Future?
description: Ratings were down and polls barely budged. Did the August conventions offer a road map for saving a flailing political institution?
content: After 18 hours of speeches by the candidates, testimonials from former presidents and generals, poignant appeals from voters, a cross-country nominating roll call, opera on a White House balcony and fireworks over the Washington Monument, the verdict is in on the national political conventions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Photographs by Alec Soth
title: One City. Two Neighborhoods. A 30-Year Gap in Life Expectancy.
description: A view of income inequality in Chicago at ground level.
content: A view of income inequality in Chicago at ground level.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert and Joe Drape
title: The First Saturday in ... September
description: The Kentucky Derby, the oldest continuously held sporting event in the U.S., will be run without fans for the first time. Here’s what you need to know.
content: The Kentucky Derby, the oldest continuously held sporting event in the U.S., will be run without fans for the first time. Here’s what you need to know.
source.name: The New York Times
